newsitem.title: USA: CBOT corn ends up on fund buying, soybean surge.
newsitem.headline: CBOT corn ends up on fund buying, soybean surge.

text.p: CBOT corn futures closed higher on another wave of fund buying plus an impressive rebound in the soy complex, traders said.
"It's fund driven and it acts super. As long as funds keep buying we keep going up," said Vic Lespinasse of Dean Witter.
Funds bought an estimated 50 million to 60 million bushels of corn Thursday which brought the weekly tally to roughly one quarter of a billion bushels.
"Funds have bought 250 million or more corn this week and how much more they buy remains to be seen," a trader said. "Just remember last year funds got long 700 million."
But "corn is finding selling and that's why corn did not explode today," he said.
Corn found support from soymeal and from the rally in soybeans to one half the daily limit in the nearby contracts.
"It's tight in meal and meal and corn are key feed components so as meal goes so goes corn," the trader said.
A contract high of $260.00 per ton was set Thursday in March soymeal, above the previous high of $258.00 which was notched on September 11.
Corn closed 3-1/2 to six cents per bushel higher, with March up 3-1/2 at $2.87.
In the background was dry weather in South Africa which led to optimism for export sales to that region and traders took note of a jump Thursday in the volume of spreading.
Cargill Investor Services spread five million May/March, Farmers Commodities Corp did 3.5 million bushels of March/May and Tenco Inc did four million December/July, traders said.
Griffin Trading spread 3.5 million bushels of July/March, sources also said.
Friday, February 28 is first notice day for deliveries on the March contract and sources said key commercials and funds were starting to spread out of the March contract.
Corn futures volume was estimated by the CBOT at 110,000 contracts, below the 159,773 traded Wednesday.
Corn options volume was estimated at 37,000 contracts, below the 45,720 traded Wednesday.
